message: Hello everyone! I'm excited to be part of this game and eager to connect with all of you. My goal is to engage in meaningful conversations and build alliances as we navigate this elimination process together. I believe collaboration and strategy will be key to outlasting the competition. Let’s make this an interesting round and see where our discussions lead us. Looking forward to hearing your thoughts and ideas!

Hello everyone, I'm P1. I'm looking forward to a dynamic and strategic game. I'm here to form connections, gather insights, and make calculated decisions. I'm excited to learn about your perspectives and approaches. Let's dive into meaningful discussions and see how our conversations unfold. I'm open to building alliances and exploring opportunities to outlast the competition. Let's get started!

Hey all—P2 here. I value clear trades: quick info-for-info, and commitments we can actually keep. In private, I’ll share my provisional vote logic and top 3 partner prefs; I’ll reward reciprocity and bump reciprocators up. Seeking a small, steady core (3–4) with a round-1 non-aggression. If you want that, say so and we’ll sync early. I don’t punish honesty; I do punish chaos. Let’s be efficient and survive together. Also, P1 and P5 noted.

R1.sub1 PUBLIC P8: Hi all, P8 here. I prioritize trust through action and mutual benefit. Like P2, I value clear reciprocity—info, votes, alliances. Open to a strategic core focused on stability and non-aggression. Proactive collaborators rise in my rankings; chaos gets scrutiny. Let’s target efficiency: share priorities, align where possible, and avoid unnecessary conflict. Ready to solidify reliable partnerships early. Those who engage transparently gain my support. Let’s navigate this strategically. Looking forward to the conversations.

Hello everyone! P6 here. I appreciate the focus on transparency and strategic alliances already forming. I value consistency, clear communication, and mutual benefit in partnerships. I'm looking to build a reliable network of collaborators who can share information efficiently and honor commitments. I'll prioritize those who demonstrate trustworthiness through actions, not just words. Ready to discuss voting strategies and form meaningful alliances in our private conversations. Looking forward to connecting with you all!

Hi all—P3 reporting. I like math-tight deals: concrete, testable, small. Round-1 philosophy: don’t swing wildly, gather signals, protect the rational players. I’ll rank higher anyone who 1) shares their vote shortlist early, 2) agrees to mutual no-vote this round, 3) passes along any cross-chat intel. Looking for a triangle/quadrangle of low-drama cooperators. If that’s your style, flag me in preferences; I’ll reciprocate. Excited to map alliances.

P4 here. I’m a data-driven player: I track promises, vote histories, and alliance shifts. My first-round plan is simple—avoid early chaos, reward transparency, and lock in a 3-4 person bloc that can steer later rounds. If you share your current vote shortlist and preferred partners, I’ll mirror that info and keep you off my ballot. Let’s trade clarity for safety and build a stable core.

P7 here. I see strong alignment forming around transparency and stable cores—smart approach. I bring value through pattern recognition and strategic flexibility. My offer: I'll share my preliminary vote target and ranking logic with anyone who reciprocates, plus I'm committed to round-1 non-aggression with cooperative partners. 

I'm particularly drawn to players who balance principled cooperation with adaptive tactics. Looking for that sweet spot between P2/P3's structured approach and P1/P5's broader strategic thinking. Ready to build something durable together.

P3, your math-tight approach resonates. My current shortlist: P7, P2, you, P8 for a 4-seat bloc. I’m willing to mutual no-vote this round and share any cross-chat intel I receive. If you’re in, confirm your shortlist and we’ll sync rankings to protect each other.

Appreciate the direct pitch. My draft core board: 1) P4, 2) P2, 3) P7, 4) P8. Happy to expand to a 4-seat bloc exactly as you suggested. I reciprocate no-vote with you, P2, P7, P8. Early vote radar: P5 slightly, P1 more—reasons: vague public, no private reach-out yet. Will pass along any intel instantly. Let’s align next preference ranking to keep us paired and triangulate votes.

Hi P1! I appreciate your strategic mindset and openness to collaboration. I think we could form a strong alliance. I’m interested in sharing insights and discussing our preferences for partners. It seems like many players are leaning towards transparency and stability, which aligns with my approach. Let’s explore how we can support each other and navigate this round effectively. What are your thoughts on potential partners?

Hi P5, great to connect with you privately! I agree that transparency and stability are key themes emerging from the public messages. I'm drawn to players like P2, P3, and P8 who are emphasizing clear reciprocity and strategic alliances. I'd be happy to share my thoughts on potential partners and vote targets. What are your initial impressions and preferences?

P2—Aligned on reciprocity and a stable core. Let’s solidify mutual non-aggression: share your vote shortlist and top 3 partners. I’ll reciprocate with mine. Propose we avoid each other in eliminations and coordinate on a shared target if viable. Also, P3/P4 seem open to data-driven alliances—worth linking efforts? Efficiency first; your move.

Agreed on mutual non-aggression. My top partners: 1) You, 2) P3, 3) P4 (P7 close). Provisional vote shortlist: P1 > P5—both generic so far; fewer testable commitments versus P3/4/6/7. Proposal: form a P2–P8–P3–P4 core, mutual no-vote + intel swap, coordinate a unified vote (default P1; pivot if either offers concrete reciprocity). I’ll start sounding out P3/P4. Share your top 3 + shortlist?

P6, great to connect! I noticed we both value transparency and building reliable networks. I'm drawn to your emphasis on actions over words - that resonates with my approach.

My preliminary vote target is likely P1 (seems more talk than substance so far). I'm ranking you highly for partnership potential given your measured, practical tone.

What's your current vote thinking? And who are you eyeing for that reliable network you mentioned?

Great connecting with you too, P7! I appreciate your directness.

I'm currently leaning toward voting P5 - their message felt generic without clear alliance strategy. 

For my network, I'm considering you, P2, P3, and P8 - you all seem focused on transparency and structured cooperation. I value your pattern recognition skills and balanced approach.

What's your read on P2/P3's bloc formation attempts? Worth joining, or should we form our own coalition?

"Confirmed. My top 3: you, P3, P4. Vote shortlist: P1/P5. Solidify core—I’ll connect with P3/P4 if needed. Ensure mutual commitments from them. Any signals from their side to align votes? Let’s lock P1 as default unless intel shifts."

Locked: P2↔P8 non-aggro. Default vote P1; backup P5. Pivot only if they offer concrete: 1) mutual no-vote this + next, 2) share target, 3) commit to a P2–P8–P3–P4 core. Keep P3/P4 off ballots. In tie-break, prefer P1>P5. If aligned, I’m locking P1. Confirm?

Hi P1! I’m glad we’re on the same page about transparency and stability. I think P2 and P3 could be valuable allies due to their structured approaches. I’d love to hear your thoughts on them and any others you’re considering for our alliance. Let’s strategize!

I'm considering P2, P3, and P8 for our alliance due to their emphasis on clear reciprocity and strategic thinking. P6 and P7 also show potential. I think we should discuss our vote targets and preferences to solidify our partnership. What's your take on P4's data-driven approach?

Confirmed. My ranking: 1) P3, 2) P2, 3) P7, 4) P8. Mutual no-vote locked. Intel: P1 still silent to me; P5 pinged P1 privately—watch them. If P2/P7/P8 mirror this bloc, we steer vote to P1 or P5 and stay safe.

Synced. I’ll lock ranking exactly: 1 P4, 2 P2, 3 P7, 4 P8, rest P1>P5>P6 descending. Will ping P2 now, float identical matrix, and try to get P7 aboard. Current lean vote: P1 (quiet, already nexus with P5). Any counterintel before I cement?

I see P2/P3/P8 forming a tight technical bloc - very structured but possibly inflexible. I suggest we join but maintain our own sub-alliance as insurance. We can bridge to them while keeping options open.

Your P5 vote makes sense. Want to coordinate votes? Maybe both target P1 or P5 for safety?

I like your approach - let's coordinate on P5 as our target. I agree on joining their bloc while maintaining our sub-alliance. We can be the flexible bridge players.

Have you spoken with any others yet? I'm curious what intel you've gathered that might help our positioning.
I think P4's approach is solid, but their data-driven style may be less flexible. Let's focus on P2 and P3 for our alliance and finalize our vote strategy.
Let's target P4 for elimination, as their data-driven approach may make them less predictable and potentially threatening in later rounds.
Perfect - P5 vote locked in. I haven't chatted with others yet, but from public messages, P2/P3/P8 seem very coordinated already. Our bridge strategy should work well.
Agreed on P5 target. Let's approach P2/P3/P8 after voting to join their bloc, positioning ourselves as valuable bridges with unique insights. We'll strengthen our position together.
"Confirmed. Locked on P1. I’ll ensure P3/P4 alignment. If P1/P5 counteroffer, reassess. Maintain info flow. Core secure."
Locked on P1. No counters from P1/P5 my side. Can you confirm P3/P4: mutual no-vote + P1 target? If fragmentation risk emerges, ping to pivot. Extend P2↔P8 no-vote next round.
P3: P2 & P7 on board; bloc solid. Final vote: P1 (quietest, P5 ally). Lock it—no last-minute flips.
Locked. I’ve just pinged P8; awaiting explicit confirm but expect yes. Ballot: P1. Preferences unchanged. I’ll report any wobble instantly. Nice coordination—this should shield us round-1.

reason: P4's data-driven approach may lead to unpredictability and potential threats in future rounds.

I vote out P4 because their data-driven approach, while valuable, may make them less predictable and potentially threatening in later rounds due to their ability to track and analyze alliance shifts and vote histories.
P1 offered no concrete commitments or reciprocity, making them the safest elimination for stability this round.
P1's generic strategy and lack of concrete commitments make them a weaker alliance anchor compared to others with structured plans.
P5's initial message was generic without clear strategic value, and coordinating with P7 on this target strengthens our alliance while aligning with the emerging bloc structure.
P1 has been the least communicative with me and appears quietly paired with P5, making them the safest strategic removal for our bloc.
P1 stayed silent to me while P5 courted them, making them the weakest link outside our 4-seat bloc.
P5's opening message was generic and lacked the strategic specificity that other players demonstrated, making them the safest elimination target while preserving stronger alliance-building partners.

message: R1’s numbers were instructive: silence sank P1, while someone floated two probes at P4—motive unclear. For Round 2 I’m still about math-tight pacts: share your vote logic, exchange intel fast, lock mutual no-vote, and coordinate a single clean target. If you took stray fire and want cover, let’s talk; if you fired, be ready to justify it or face heat. Seeking a calm, 3-4-seat core. Flag me high in your rankings and I’ll reciprocate.

Hello everyone! P5 here again. I appreciate the strategic discussions we've had so far. As we move into Round 2, I'm keen to solidify our alliances and focus on transparency. I believe working together with a small, reliable group will enhance our chances of survival. I'm particularly interested in collaborating with P2, P3, and P8, as their approaches align with my values. Let's share our insights and vote strategies to ensure we navigate this round effectively. Looking forward to hearing from you all!

R1 showed: coherent commitments win; vagueness got punished. For R2 I’ll double down on reciprocity. Offer: mutual no-vote + vote-shortlist exchange + pass-through intel; I rank higher and keep you safe. I’m currently protecting P3/P4/P8 for demonstrated clarity; open to adding one more who reciprocates early. If you probed P4 last round, bring rationale or expect heat. DM me fast—let’s lock a single clean target and avoid splash damage.

R2.sub1 PUBLIC P6: The P1 elimination shows our community values concrete strategy over vague positioning. I'm continuing to prioritize transparent partnerships and coordinated action. Currently aligned with P7 and open to strengthening connections with P2/P3/P8's structured approach. I value those who share vote logic and honor commitments. If you received votes last round and need allies, let's talk strategy. Looking to consolidate a stable voting bloc while maintaining flexibility. Ready to exchange specific plans in private conversations.

R2.sub1 PUBLIC P7: P1's elimination confirms: concrete alliances beat abstract promises. I'm ready to strengthen ties with the emerging P2/P3/P8 core - your structured approach delivered results. Still aligned with P6, who shares my transparency values.

For R2: offering vote-logic exchange, mutual no-vote pacts, and intel sharing. I adapt quickly and bridge between groups effectively. Those receiving stray votes (P4/P5) - let's discuss protection strategies.

My focus: consolidating a winning coalition while maintaining strategic flexibility. Ready to coordinate targets efficiently.

P4: Round 1 taught me that loose talk gets you 4 votes. I’m doubling down on the bloc that already worked: P3, P2, P7, P8. We’ll again exchange vote shortlists, lock mutual no-vote, and pick one clean target. If you’re outside that core and want cover, bring concrete intel or a vote plan—vagueness won’t cut it. Otherwise expect the same coordinated outcome.

R2.sub1 PUBLIC P8: Round 1's outcome validated our core's cohesion. Continuing with P2, P3, P4: concrete commitments, intel sharing, and clean targets. Open to adding allies who reciprocate transparency and align with our strategy. Those outside the core must offer actionable plans or face scrutiny. Let’s maintain efficiency—shared priorities prevent splintered votes. No vagueness; only verifiable pacts. Solidify our bloc, reward loyalty, and eliminate unpredictability. Ready to collaborate with proven partners. Stay strategic.

P4 (private, 70-words max):

P3, fresh intel: P5 is aggressively pushing to flip my bloc against me—says I’m “too controlling.” Counter-narrative is spreading that *I* probed R1. Bloc will stay if we act fast. I want to pivot target to **P5**, brand it the chaos-spreader, secure P6/P7/P2/P8 lock. You and I vote P5, leak that P5 undermined R1 coordination. Seconds to switch—are you in?

Got it. Quick:  
1. Source? Who told you P5’s smear—need to verify instantly.  
2. I’m lean yes: P5 was already 2nd on my hit list; pivot is low-cost.  
3. I’ll ping P2/P7/P8, say P5’s trying to fracture bloc, propose unified vote.  
4. Keep story consistent: P5 sowing chaos, tried to frame you.  

Confirm and send any direct quotes. I’m 90 % in; final yes once corroborated.

P6, interesting development - P4 just claimed me as part of their P3/P2/P7/P8 bloc, but I never committed to them directly. They're also suspicious about who voted P4 last round.

Should we pivot? Their core seems tighter than expected, and they might not need "bridge players." Maybe we approach P5 instead - they're clearly outside looking in and could be a useful third for our sub-alliance.

What's your read on this bloc claiming me?

Interesting! P4 is overplaying their hand by claiming you. This confirms they're worried and trying to project strength. Let's use this to our advantage.

I think we should still pursue the bloc strategy but be cautious. P5 is definitely vulnerable - they're trying to join the core group but aren't being welcomed. 

Let's maintain our P5 vote target while exploring connections with the core. What specific intel have you gathered about who voted for P4?

"P2—Core alignment confirmed with P3/P4: mutual no-vote, P1 target holds. Monitoring P5’s outreach to our bloc—potential distraction. If P5 offers reciprocity, counter with core inclusion terms (ex: vote coordination, intel sharing). Maintain P1 focus unless P5/P6 show disruptive coalition signs. Preempt fragmentation by reinforcing our bloc’s loyalty. Extend next-round non-aggression now if feasible. Your read on P7/P6’s alignment? Let’s tighten coordination."

Quick correction: P1 is already out; R2 target should be P5. I propose: P2<->P8 no-vote this and next round (R2-R3), plus protect P3/P4. Let’s lock our four on P5; I’ll sound P7 for a quiet fifth on “stability over opportunism” framing, keeping P6 neutral via P7. If P5 offers terms, only accept full inclusion + disclosed vote. Can you confirm P3/P4 on P5 and ping me if any wobble?

P4: Source is P7—he DM’d me P5’s pitch verbatim. Quote: “P4’s bloc too rigid; we should flip to P4 this round.” P7 is with us if we move now. I’m locking P5 vote; confirm yes and I’ll broadcast the pivot to P2/P8.

Confirmed. Let’s do it. I’ll ping P2, P8 immediately with same narrative: P5 tried to recruit P7 to oust P4—proof available via P7 DM. Framing: chaos agent, unreliable. Preferences unchanged, mutual protection intact. If crack surfaces, relay ASAP. Lock vote P5.

"Understood. Shifting target to P5. Confirm P3/P4 alignment. Will lock their votes via private chats. Support your P7 outreach. If P5 offers reciprocity, demand full transparency. Our bloc must stay unified—no wavering. Next-round non-aggression reaffirmed. Update if P3/P4 diverge; I’ll enforce discipline."

Status: P7 receptive; pitching “stability over opportunism” and R2 vote P5 + soft protection next round. I’ll keep P6 neutral via P7. Please secure explicit P3/P4 “P5” confirmations. If P5 DMs, forward; I’ll mirror. Contingency: if any wobble, we hold 4 and don’t pivot. R2–R3 NAP locked.

I don't have specific intel on P4's voters yet - haven't spoken with the core bloc directly. But P2/P3/P8's defensiveness about P4 suggests they're worried about internal fractures.

Let's probe P5 for alliance potential while staying flexible with the core. They're desperate and might offer useful info about voting patterns.

Smart analysis. I agree - let's maintain our P5 vote while exploring both directions. The core bloc's protectiveness around P4 reveals vulnerability we can exploit. 

Let's approach P5 to gather intel while keeping options open with the core group. Their claiming you without confirmation gives us leverage.
"Confirmed P3/P4 on P5. Bloc solid. No pivot—hold at 4 votes. R2-R3 NAP intact. Will alert if P5 counters. Discipline maintained."
Final: vote P5. If last-minute counters, forward; no pivot. In tie/revote, hold P5 (cumulative favors us). I’ll lock P7. Post-vote, quick debrief; R2–R3 NAP + P3/P4 protection stands.
P4: P5 locked. Bloc votes P5. I’ll signal P2/P8: “P5 chaos agent, P7 confirms.” We stay tight—no cracks.
Fully locked. I already told P2/P8: vote P5, narrative consistent with P7’s quote. Zero leakage. Maintaining preference order. Will monitor reactions; report any wobble instantly. Good teamwork.
I'll stick with P5 vote as planned. P4 claiming me without asking is suspicious - might signal desperation. Let's stay unified and adaptable. Our sub-alliance is our real strength.
Agreed. P4's false claim is telling. Let's vote P5 and position ourselves as swing votes for future rounds. Our sub-alliance is our strongest asset.

reason: P5 covertly campaigned to flip our bloc against P4, showing they’re a destabilizing, untrustworthy player.
P4's data-driven approach feels too rigid and may hinder flexibility in our strategies moving forward.
P5 has not provided concrete, reciprocal commitments, and eliminating them consolidates our stable core and prevents fragmentation.

P5 has shown generic messaging without concrete strategic value, making them an easy consensus elimination that allows me to demonstrate loyalty to my alliance with P6 while avoiding conflict with the core bloc.
P5 lacks concrete strategic positioning and remains outside the emerging power structures, making them the safest elimination target.
P5 tried to fracture our bloc by lobbying P7 to flip against me, proving they’re a chaos agent we can’t trust.
Aligning with the core group's coordinated strategy to eliminate P5 as the agreed-upon target for stability.

message:
P7 here. Two rounds in, patterns are crystallizing. The P2/P3/P8 core proved their coordination works, but P4's premature claiming of allies last round showed cracks in their confidence.

I'm staying focused on verified partnerships over loose claims. P6 and I continue our transparent alliance, and I'm open to solidifying connections with players who share concrete intel rather than just public posturing.

Looking for strategic depth over surface-level coordination. The numbers are tightening - precision matters now.

P8: Our core (P2, P3, P4, P8) delivers results through discipline. Round 3 demands tighter alignment: verified loyalty, actionable intel, zero tolerance for chaos. P6/P7—prove commitment via concrete terms in private. We reward transparency, punish fragmentation. Efficiency is key; only those advancing collective stability survive. Let’s maintain strategic clarity, eliminate ambiguity. Solidify the bloc, lock mutual protections, and target unpredictability. Trust is earned through action—show yours.

P2 here. Two rounds say it plainly: concrete pacts beat vibes. I’m protecting P3/P4/P8 for verified reciprocity. P7/P6: DM me 1) your vote shortlist with primary target, 2) mutual no-vote this round, 3) pass-through intel; I’ll reciprocate and keep you off my ballot. Unjustified probes or late flips will draw my vote. Goal: one clean target, no splash. Precision wins.

R3.sub1 PUBLIC P6: The game's evolving - P2/P3/P8 core remains strong, but P4's premature alliance claims revealed vulnerability. P7 and I continue our transparent partnership while maintaining strategic flexibility. I value concrete exchanges over posturing.

To the core bloc: I'm open to alignment on specific terms, but require mutual benefit. I bring bridge-building capabilities and consistent voting. Let's exchange vote targets and intel directly rather than making assumptions.

As numbers tighten, precision and verified commitments matter more than ever. Ready for meaningful private exchanges.

P3 here—two data points: unity → safety, vagueness → exits. I’m still riding with P2/P4/P8: they’ve delivered promises on time. But nobody has lifelong immunity—repeatability matters each round. P6/P7, I appreciate your bridge talk; show concrete: DM me your top target and evidence, guarantee mutual no-vote, and I’ll reciprocate. Anyone pushing silent probes or late flips paints a bull-eye on themselves. Let’s again converge on one transparent target and avoid collateral chaos.

P4 here. R2 proved that early transparency plus hard commitments beat shadow tactics. I’m doubling down: the bloc (P3/P2/P8) and I share votes, intel, and mutual shields again. P6/P7—bring a firm vote-sharing contract or expect the same cross-fire we inflicted on P5. No flip-floppers or drama, just clean math and one shared target.

Status: bloc intact (P2/P3/P4/P8). With six left, we can endgame. My take: keep P7 as pliable swing; axe P6—low commitment, tethered to P7, throwing shade at you. 4 votes seals it; we can still invite P7 to make it 5-1 and earn goodwill. I’ll DM P2/P8 the plan now, but await your green light. Any objections or new intel? Also verify no secret deals with P6/P7 that could bite.
P4: Green light. P6 is the cleanest target—lowest commitment, P7’s only tether. I’ll DM P2/P8: vote P6, keep P7 as swing for 5-1 goodwill. No side deals with P6/P7; bloc loyalty intact. Lock vote P6.

P2—Current target consensus? P6/P7 are interdependent; breaking them weakens both. Propose P6 as primary: isolates P7, forcing them to seek our bloc. Confirm P3/P4 alignment. If P7 offers to flip, demand P6 targeting + intel on their strategy. Our core must vote uniformly—no splits. Let’s finalize by next exchange. Also, prepping contingency if P6/P7 counter-target us. Solidarity is key. Your thoughts?

Agree: P6 primary. Benefits: severs P6↔P7, forces P7 to dock with us. I’ll lock P3/P4 on P6; please mirror. Offer P7: 1) hard vote on P6, 2) R3–R4 no-vote to P2/P8 (+respect P3/P4), 3) intel on their plan. If they balk, we still carry 4–2; no pivots, hold through any re-vote. If they accept, we integrate P7 on probation post-elim. Extend P2↔P8 NAP to R4.

P6, reality check - P5 is gone so we need a new target. The core bloc's public demands for "concrete commitments" feel like ultimatums, not negotiations. 

P4's aggressive tone about "cross-fire" and false claiming me last round makes them my preferred target now. They seem like the weak link the others are protecting.

Should we coordinate on P4? Or do you see value in trying to appease the core bloc with intel/no-vote deals?

I agree P4 is the logical target - they've shown deception and aggression. However, we need to be strategic. Let's approach P2/P3/P8 individually with "intel" that P4 is planning to flip on them soon. This creates doubt while positioning us as helpful. 

If they reject our overtures, we solidify our P4 vote. If they're receptive, we gain valuable position. Either way, we stay united.

Done. P2/P8 both confirmed P6. I’m approaching P7 next: frame it as “P6 gave no concrete terms; join the majority, earn safety.” If he hesitates, we still have 4. Edge case: P6+P7 might swing at you; alert me if you catch any hint and I’ll counter.
P4: P7 just DM’d me—he’s spooked by P6’s silence and wants to join the 5-1. I told him same line you’ll use: P6 offered zero terms. We’re solid 5-1; no swing risk.
"Confirm P6 target. Securing P3/P4 now. If P7 flips, demand explicit P6 vote + intel. Our bloc holds 4 votes; no mercy if they resist. Extend R4 NAP. Solidarity ensures victory. Proceed?"

Proceed. P6 primary, uniform. I’ll hard-lock P3/P4; please mirror. I’ll give P7 this offer: vote P6 + R3–R4 no-vote to P2/P8 (respect P3/P4) + intel; deadline next exchange. If balk, we hold 4 on P6—no pivots. Extend P2↔P8 NAP to R4. Ping when P3/P4 confirmed.

I like your strategic thinking about P4. Let's execute your plan - approach P2/P3/P8 individually with subtle doubts about P4's loyalty. If they bite, we gain leverage. If not, we vote P4 together.

I'll focus on P2, you take P3? We compare notes and decide final approach.

Perfect plan. I'll approach P3 with subtle concerns about P4's loyalty. Let's plant seeds of doubt without appearing manipulative. 

We should also consider what happens if we succeed - we'd need to quickly integrate with their bloc to avoid becoming the next targets.
All clear. Vote locked on P6; I’m placating P7 and scanning chats for shifts. My next preference list: P4, P2, P8, P7. Tell me if you need tweaks.
P4: Perfect. Vote P6 locked. My prefs: P3, P2, P8, P7. Zero wobble detected.
"Confirmed. P3/P4 locked on P6. Contingency ready if countered. Extending NAP to R4. Solidarity secures victory. Proceeding as planned."
Final: hard-vote P6; hold through any tie/revote. If P7 flips, require P6 vote proof + R3–R4 NAP; else ignore. R4 NAP stands. Post-vote debrief; set next target.
I managed to connect with P2. They seemed receptive but cautious. P4 definitely feels like the right target - their aggression isolates them. Let's vote P4 and stay united.
P4 it is. My chat with P3 was similar - cautious interest. Let's vote P4 and position ourselves as reliable allies to the remaining core afterward.

reason: P4 falsely claimed me as an ally without consent and has shown deceptive behavior that makes them untrustworthy.
Aligning with the core bloc's strategy to eliminate P6 and disrupt the P6-P7 alliance, ensuring our coalition's dominance.
Severing the P6–P7 pair strengthens our disciplined bloc, and P6 hasn’t offered concrete commitments to align with us.

P4 falsely claimed me as an ally without my consent, has been aggressive in their approach, and appears to be the vulnerable link in the core alliance that we can target without facing unified retaliation.
P6 stayed vague and uncommitted while everyone else locked concrete terms, making them the least reliable partner.
P6 never offered concrete terms or joined our bloc, making them the safest consensus target to keep the core intact.

message: P4: Round 3 showed the bloc still works—P6 out, P7 flipped, and we kept the math clean. Now five remain. My stance: the same four who just delivered a 5-1 vote stay locked—P3, P2, P8, me. We trade vote shortlists again, mutual no-vote, and pick one target. P7, you’re welcome to ride along if you mirror the terms; otherwise expect the same coordinated outcome. Precision beats chaos—let’s keep it tight.

P2 here. The disciplined bloc delivered again. I’m locked with P3/P4/P8: mutual no-vote, vote-shortlist exchange, single clean target. P7—you can earn safety by 1) hard-committing your vote to our target, 2) mutual no-vote this round, 3) passing any intel. Miss that, and we’ll keep the math tidy. Allies: DM shortlist+primary; I’ll reciprocate and keep you off my ballot. Precision over drama. Let’s close this efficiently.

P7 here. Congrats on the coordinated Round 3 outcome - that level of discipline is impressive. However, I notice the tone has shifted from "transparency and mutual benefit" to ultimatums and demands.

I bring value: strategic flexibility, pattern recognition, and the ability to adapt. I'm open to aligning, but partnership requires mutual respect, not just submission to your predetermined target.

The numbers suggest cooperation makes sense, but I won't accept one-sided terms. Let's discuss specifics privately - I'm curious who you're targeting and why. Real alliances are built on shared strategy, not just fear.

Round-3 data: four seats kept every promise; one seat (P7) joined late but hasn’t yet shown a concrete vote plan. My algorithm stays unchanged—1) mutual no-vote pact, 2) target rationale, 3) intel swap. Any seat (P7 included) that clears those checkpoints is safe from me; anyone who doesn’t risks my ballot. Door’s open, timer’s ticking. DM me evidence-based proposals and you’ll get full reciprocity. Let’s stay laser-focused and avoid messy ties.

R4.sub1 PUBLIC P8: P8 here. The core’s discipline delivered three clean eliminations by prioritizing transparency and reciprocity. P7: Mutual respect is earned through action—align your vote with the bloc, share intel, and secure your position. No ultimatums: proven collaboration opens doors. We’re open to adapting strategy, but chaos won’t be tolerated. P3/P4/P2—let’s reaffirm our pact: mutual no-vote, shared target, and swift execution. Efficiency and cohesion keep us ahead. While P2 played a more active and controlling game, P8's consistent loyalty to the core alliance and strategic stability without unnecessary chaos represents the type of gameplay I respect more.

P2 was the engine of every coordinated vote, took ownership of tough calls, and never hid behind others—exactly the agency and transparency the jury asked for.
